displayed_text: Doctor: Didn’t mean to interrupt you. Doctor: The light’s going to stay on? Family Member: She’s upstairs. Doctor: New patient? Family Member: Yep. Doctor: Oh, okay. Family Member: Study patient. Well, not study. Off study. Doctor: But, oh my. Oh my. Family Member: Hi, Dr. H___. Doctor: Hi. Lovely to see your father. (Laughs) Doctor: It’s amazing. Just waiting on the final stuff from administration. Everything else is okeydokey. So he’ll take his time filling out this lovely paperwork while you do damage control and try to fix our inpatient unit, please. Doctor: Shoot. Patient: I’ve got several questions for ya now. If I get the drug, what are the most common side effects?

Patient: Alright. Doctor: Back off a little. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. Sit tight. You know who’s coming next. Patient: My buddy. Doctor: M___. Patient: Oh, M___. Doctor: Oh. Patient: My papers. I’m going to have paper to sign this way. Doctor: Of course. There’s always papers to sign. Patient: How long do you think before we actually start? Doctor: Uh, well it’s up to you but probably in a week or two. I wanna to get going. Patient: Okay.

Family Member: But the lack of rest contributes to a lot of issues for both of us. Doctor: Um hum. Sure. Yeah. That will help with uh you feeling better during the day, too. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: Right. I see what you mean. Okay. So let me have S___ come in – Family Member: Okay. Doctor: -and give you a copy of the consent. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But once we found out, she will be in touch. Family Member: Thank you. Doctor: To let you know what we’re going to do. Family Member: Okay. Patient: Okay.

Patient: I stopped doing that quite a while ago. Family Member 1: Yeah, that's what he said about a couple of weeks ago. He stopped. He's giving her separated. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 1: Okay, now, M_____'s pregnant, she picked up his water and drank the whole water the other day by accident. I don't know. Doctor: That's okay. Yeah, I think where when you're on chemo, you have to use universal precautions, you know. So it's always easier if you have more than one bathroom in your home. So that even if you have your own bathroom space where your towels and you can have Lysol and things. You feel comfortable. That's just his bathroom, so that you don't always constantly have to Lysol and Clorox things. Patient: Right. Doctor: If you have only one bathroom you'll just be very diligent you'll get some gloves you wipe down after you use the bathroom with because chemo- Family Member: With what? Doctor: Oh with Lysol Clorox anything over the counter you got the wipes. They all work. Family Member 1: Wipes work? Flush twice? Doctor: Yep flush twice and then with the wipes put them in the garbage, but just keep it separate. Patient: Right.

Family Member: Oh! Doctor: So it wasn’t by choice. Healthcare Professional: What kind of car did you get? Family Member: Did you get your Caddy? Doctor: I did not. No, he wanted me to get a Cadillac. No, no, I got a Mercedes. Family Member: Oh, all right! Patient: Something smaller; it’s easier to drive. Doctor: Yeah. Healthcare Professional: A car or SUV? Doctor: Yeah, I didn’t want the big tank of a car. Family Member: No, so you have the car. Doctor: No, it’s not an SUV. I didn’t want the SUV.

Patient: I don’t know what you think about that because that lesion is right where the nerve is pinched and I don’t know if he goes in there and stirs things up uh… Doctor: Well. Patient: He’s he’s not for sure yet. The last time I saw him he said I don’t want to open a whole can of worms and I told him if you can’t make it better… I can live with it, I can live with it. Doctor: Although their main reasoning was that there was disc issues and arthritis more the bigger problem for the nerve than… Patient: Right. Doctor: …the cancer. Patient: Right. Doctor: and… Patient: But the cancer… Doctor: You know but at the time the cancer was also acting up so I said let me treat the cancer. Patient: Right. Doctor: Let’s see if that makes any change. It hasn’t changed, but it didn’t get worse either so…

Patient: I need two weeks off. Doctor: Yeah. No, no, no, we’ll figure it out. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s just keep things moving and we’ll figure it out. Patient: So J___ told me that his promise to you is he said he’ll get me squared away medically and then - Doctor: Yes, and then it’s time for us to take over! (chuckles) Patient: Yeah. ___ called me last night. He said we’re taking a break in oncology and we’re going to do some medicine. And I said okay. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: That really made me feel good, for you, too, and for me. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Because I was like “You’ve got to do that or I get derailed from what I have to do.” Patient: Right. Doctor: So he’s on it.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: I appreciate both of you coming in. I really do. Patient: Well, thank you. I appreciate the time that you spend. Doctor: Oh, of course. I just wanted to wrap everything, yeah, because, you know, this always happens in medicine, right, we have one path and we’re like we’re going this way, it’s like no, everybody to the left, everybody to the left. We’re just regrouping. We’re just regrouping. Thank you both. Patient: Thank you. Doctor: I’ll get all the paperwork, get your scans set up and I’ll see you guys next week. Patient: Alright. That sounds good. Saturday we’re still… Doctor: Oh, that’s great. Come hungry for breakfast because the buffet is like. Patient: Alright. Great. Doctor: Yeah, it’s the best part, I mean other than the speaker. Patient: Right. Doctor: See you guys.

Patient: Yeah. I was thinking to go down Y___. Doctor: Okay. Yeah. You can go there, definitely. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Or, you know, at SM___’s, there is a neurosurgeon who’s very good. Family Member: Now, does he ever see, does he have-? Patient: SM___’s, where? Doctor: Here, L___, so, like a few miles from here. Patient: Oh, L___, oh. Could you get me the, his card, or something? Doctor: I’ll give you his phone number, yeah. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. He’s specifically a spine surgeon. I’ve known him for many years. Patient: Oh, I see. Okay. Family Member: Oh. That makes sense.

Family Member: We stand, we stand in agreement with you. Doctor: Okay. But the good news is that you’re feeling well and the bone disease really did not get any worse. Family Member: Right. That’s good. Doctor: You know? You didn’t have any new areas, nothing else. Family Member: That’s a blessing. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. Your pain and everything else overall is pretty well controlled. Family Member: Yes. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So I’m good with that. Family Member: Um hum. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Alright?

Family Member: Yeah Doctor: Between your kidney’s failing and hurting and the infections, I mean there were multiple other things that were being thrown at us. Family Member: Yeah and he’s showing an improvement in between – in most all areas… Doctor: The treatment is working and things are looking up. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: That’s why we’re so glad to be here but you’ve got some people that were mean to us this morning. Doctor: Really? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Why? Family Member: They told us… Doctor: What did they tell you?

Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: and you know, depending on what your scans show, I actually would favor Provenge, which is the vaccine therapy, because it’s almost like a flu shot. We don’t really know what happens to the PSA but we do know that if you get it in people who get it Patient: Is that a shot or is that through? Doctor: So, here’s where it gets a little complicated. You know, the flu shot is also like a vaccine. That, you know, you just get here. But, in cancer it’s a little bit more complicated. So, what we would do is actually send you to the Red Cross right across the street. Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: They hook you up to a machine and then they take out your cells so they’re not using my cells or anybody else’s cells. They’re taking out your cells, your immune cells so that when they take it they ship it to Atlanta so if you’ve never been to Atlanta, your cells will be. They wake it up and then they ship it back to me, the like better version of you and then I reinfuse it back to you so that your cells know to find the cancer. That’s the thought of how that medicine works. So, we do that, let’s say the Red Cross on a Monday, I get your stuff back like on a Thursday and then I reinfuse it to you on a Thursday. We do that 3 times and then the treatment is done. It’s self-limited. Okay. Patient: So, that’s your immune system. Doctor: That’s the immune system. Patient: So, what happens in between, does that weaken your immune system or? Doctor: No, it actually if anything strengthens. Patient: I mean while it’s out. Doctor: Oh, no. We don’t take everything out. We just take a few things out. Patient: Oh, okay.

Patient: Yeah, she needed it. She do like me. Doctor: Okay. Patient: She’s way heavier than me. Doctor: Oh, okay. Patient: Yeah, she way heavier than me. Doctor: Alright. So, Patient: So, I say, yeah, I tell her can she get a script so I can call my insurance and see where I can get a cheap one at. Doctor: Yeah. I don’t think I will be able to justify a scooter for you. Okay? Based on just this disease. Believe me, I have given that script to other people, and it has not worked for people who are sick or older than you. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, I don’t think it will work. Okay? Uh, beyond that, if you want to see a neurologist, get tested, and see if they would be willing to give you, that’s perfectly okay with me. Patient: Uh, what, a what? Doctor: Neurologist. A nerve specialist.

Family Member: We are, but we didn’t go on there. Doctor: Okay, that's fine. Let me print this out for you so that you can see what I'm talking about. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I’ll print both of them. Because the way that we, oh no there’s a lot of stuff coming out. So let me first sort of describe what we call like the stages of prostate cancer. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: I’ll use the back of this. I think we talked about this last time, but I'll just, if I'm repeating myself and you get it, just say I remember all of this. So stages, so first you have what we call localized. Patient: Right. Doctor: -and that's when it's in the prostate. And that is when you had surgery. Okay, so the treatment here is surgery. And then we have- usually the PSA goes up and then it goes down to zero after you get your prostate taken out. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: And then it'll go back up. That is what we call biochemical recurrence. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: And that's when you have a rising PSA but negative imaging. Patient: Mm.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Like next Tuesday or next Wednesday. But I think either way, because of this anemia that has come back, uh, the trial at the very least will require us to stop the medication until the hemoglobin increases. Patient: Hum. Family Member: So are there other things that he can do like, say, for instance, you know, maybe take an iron or, but are there food products that he can eat that might help with increasing, uh, his blood? Doctor: Well, there’s many, you know, causes for anemia. And the only one of them that is helped by iron is iron-deficiency anemia. Iron-deficiency anemia is typically, one, caused by bleeding from somewhere. Family Member: Hum. Doctor: So, uh, I really don’t think you have the iron-deficiency anemia, and so, uh, I don’t think that will help that much, unfortunately. You know? I wouldn’t discourage you from taking iron if you want to. Patient: Um hum. Okay. Doctor: Or if you want to eat iron-rich foods, uh, like- Family Member: But you’re thinking this is basically because of the medication? The study medication? Doctor: Yeah. I’m pretty sure. I’m pretty sure because, I mean, he actually had some degree of mild anemia before he went on the study. Part of that could have been from the cancer of the bone or marrow, specifically, but clearly when he went on the drug, it got worse, and it dropped back one to two points. So, uh, but you might need a transfusion, however. But that’s a possibility. Patient: Um hum. Okay. Doctor: So as of today, you know, stopping the . Okay? Uh, let’s plan to do, uh, forgot what the lab was. Is it K___?

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.strongly agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::strongly agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.12 years or completed high school: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::12 years or completed high school

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.Yes, Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::Yes, Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.American Indian or Alaska Native: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::American Indian or Alaska Native
